A.definition: Anything of value that can be converted into cash.
The process of gradually writing off the initial cost of an asset.
A fixed sum of money paid to someone each year.
The simultaneous purchase and sale of an asset to profit from a difference in the price.
An increase in the value of an asset over time.

B.definition: A statement of the assets, liabilities, and capital of a business at a particular point in time.
A fixed income instrument that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower.
A market in which prices are falling, encouraging selling.
An individual or firm that acts as an intermediary between an investor and a securities exchange.

C.definition: Wealth in the form of money or other assets owned by a person or organization.
Something pledged as security for repayment of a loan.
Raw materials or primary agricultural products that can be bought and sold.
An arrangement to receive cash, goods, or services now and pay for them in the future.

D.definition: A sum of money paid regularly by a company to its shareholders out of its profits.
A reduction in the value of an asset over time.
An amount of money borrowed by one party from another.
A financial security with a value that is reliant upon or derived from an underlying asset or group of assets.
A stock market index that indicates the value of 30 large, publicly owned companies based in the United States.

E.definition: The value of an owner's interest in a property after deducting liabilities.
A type of investment fund that is traded on stock exchanges.
A company's profit divided by the outstanding shares of its common stock.
A financial arrangement where a third party holds funds or assets until a condition is met.

F.definition: Financial contracts obligating the buyer to purchase an asset at a predetermined future date and price.
A one-year period that companies and governments use for financial reporting and budgeting.
Business expenses that remain the same regardless of the level of production or sales.
The process by which a lender takes control of a property from a borrower who has failed to make payments.

G.definition: The total value of goods produced and services provided in a country during one year.
The difference between revenue and cost of goods sold divided by revenue, expressed as a percentage.
An intangible asset that arises when a buyer acquires an existing business.
A person or entity that agrees to be responsible for another's debt or obligation if they default.

H.definition: An investment to reduce the risk of adverse price movements in an asset.
A company created to own and control other companies' stock.
A type of loan in which the borrower uses the equity of their home as collateral.
Extremely rapid or out of control inflation.

I.definition: The proportion of a loan that is charged as interest to the borrower.
A mutual fund or ETF designed to follow certain preset rules so that the fund can track a specified basket of underlying investments.
The first time that the stock of a private company is offered to the public.
The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising.

J.definition: A business arrangement in which two or more parties agree to pool their resources for a specific task.
A high-yield, high-risk security, typically issued by a company seeking to raise capital quickly.
A court's decision regarding the rights and liabilities of parties in a legal action.

K.definition: A measurable value that demonstrates how effectively a company is achieving key business objectives.
A process that financial institutions and other regulated companies must perform to verify the identity of their clients.

L.definition: The availability of liquid assets to a market or company.
The use of various financial instruments or borrowed capital to increase the potential return of an investment.
A company's legal debts or obligations that arise during the course of business operations.
An individual, a public or private group, or a financial institution that makes funds available to another with the expectation that the funds will be repaid.

M.definition: The total market value of a company's outstanding shares of stock.
An investment vehicle made up of a pool of money collected from many investors to invest in securities such as stocks, bonds, and other assets.
A loan used to purchase or maintain a home, land, or other types of real estate.
The combining of two or more companies into a single entity.

N.definition: A company's total earnings, also called net profit.
An American stock exchange, the second-largest in the world by market capitalization.
A loan in which the borrower is not making interest payments or repaying any principal.

O.definition: A contract which gives the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an underlying asset at a specified price before or on a specified date.
An extension of credit from a lending institution when an account reaches zero.
All the shares of a corporation or financial asset that have been authorized, issued, and purchased by investors.

P.definition: A measure of profitability, calculated as net income divided by revenue.
A range of investments held by a person or organization.
Capital investment made into companies that are not publicly traded.
The amount of money borrowed or invested, excluding interest or earnings.

Q.definition: The profit or loss a company has made during a three-month period.
A measure of a company's ability to meet its short-term obligations with its most liquid assets.
Analysis based on subjective judgment rather than quantifiable data.

R.definition: A measure used to evaluate the efficiency or profitability of an investment.
The process of identifying, assessing, and controlling threats to an organization's capital and earnings.
The total income generated by the sale of goods or services related to the company's primary operations.
A period of temporary economic decline during which trade and industrial activity are reduced.

S.definition: A type of security that signifies ownership in a corporation and represents a claim on part of the corporation's assets and earnings.
An economic model of price determination in a market.
A type of mortgage offered to individuals with poor credit scores who are considered high-risk borrowers.
An individual or institution that legally owns a share of stock in a public or private corporation.

T.definition: A marketable, fixed-interest U.S. government debt security with a maturity of more than 10 years.
A fund consisting of assets belonging to a trust, held by the trustees for the beneficiaries.
The amount of income used to calculate how much tax an individual or a company owes to the government in a given tax year.
The amount by which the cost of a country's imports exceeds the value of its exports.

U.definition: A loan that is not backed by collateral.
The process by which an individual or institution takes on financial risk for a fee.
A measure of preferences over some set of goods and services.

V.definition: Financing provided to startups and small businesses with strong growth potential.
A statistical measure of the dispersion of returns for a given security or market index.
An investment strategy that involves picking stocks that appear to be trading for less than their intrinsic or book value.

W.definition: The difference between a company's current assets and current liabilities.
A high-level professional service that combines financial and investment advice, accounting and tax services, and legal or estate planning.
A financial instrument that gives the holder the right to purchase the company's stock at a specific price before expiration.
The amount of an employee's pay withheld by the employer and sent directly to the government as partial payment of income tax.

X.definition: A stock trading without the value of the next dividend payment.

Y.definition: The income return on an investment, such as the interest or dividends received.
A line that plots interest rates at a set point in time for bonds having equal credit quality but differing maturity dates.
A comprehensive report on a company's financial activities at the end of the fiscal year.

Z.definition: A method of budgeting in which all expenses must be justified for each new period.
A bond that is issued at a deep discount and pays no interest.
A company that needs bailouts to operate, unable to pay its debt and barely able to meet its financial obligations.
